facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 13, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Criminal No. 175 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment And order dated March 13, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Criminal No. 175 of 1964.

facts.text: Chajoo Ram was elected Sarpanch of the Nyaya Panchayat of Risia Bazar, Tehsil Nanpara, District Bahraich on October 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Chajoo Ram, appellant, was elected Sarpanch of the Nyaya Panehay of of Risia Bazar.Tehsil Nan- pora, District Bharaic at the election held for that office on October 29, 1956.

facts.text: Radhey Shyam filed an election petition against Chajoo Ram which was dismissed on June 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Radhey Shyam  respondent in this Court  who was defeated in that election filed an election petition which was dismissed on June 3, 1958.

facts.text: Injunction issued restraining the appellant from functioning as Sarpanch from December 3, 1956 to December 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: During the trial of that petition an injunction was issued restraining the appellant from functioning as a Sarpanch. That order remained in force from December 3, 1956 to December 10, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant filed affidavit dated July 6, 1960 stating that he had not been acting as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: affirming the order of a learned single Judge of that Court directing that a companyplaint be filed against the appellant for his prosecution for making a false statement in para 10 of his affidavit dated July 6, 1960 to the effect that he had number been acting as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957.

facts.text: Radhey Shyam filed writ petition W.P. No. 89 of 1960 in Allahabad High Court praying for mandamus directing enquiries into allegations against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As numberaction was taken on those companyplaints Radhey Shyam, respondent, filed a writ petition  W.P. No-. 89 of 1960  in the Allahabad High Court praying for a mandamus directing enquiries into the allegations companytained in his companyplaint against the appellant.

facts.text: Writ petition allowed on September 4, 1961 issuing writ of mandamus to District Magistrate and Sub-Divisional Magistrate to hold enquiry against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This write petition was allowed on- September 4, 1961 and a writ of mandamus was issued directing the District Magistrate and thee Sub-Divisional Magistrate to hold an enquiry against the appellant but the question of determining whether it was in public interest to hold an enquiry was left to those authorities.

facts.text: Learned single Judge directed by order dated January 27, 1964 that a complaint be made against appellant for false statement in para 10 of affidavit dated July 6, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1962 Rafhey Shyam, Respondent, Moved in the High Court an application under s.476, Cr. P.C. for the appellants prosecution. The learned single Judge directed by his order dated January 27, 1964 that a companyplaint be made against the appellant in respect of two companynts, one of them, which survives for our companysideration, being that he had made a false statement in paragraph 10 of. his affidavit dated July 6, 1960 to the effect that he had number been acting as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court affirmed single Judge order on March 13, 1968 regarding para 10.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was accordingly allowed in part and in regard to para 10 of the affidavit dated July 6, 1960 it was dismissed. It is this order which is assailed before us.

facts.text: Radhey Shyam filed rejoinder affidavit dated July 15, 1960 denying that Chajoo Ram did not act as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957 and alleging he acted throughout in violation of stay order.

anchor.surface_text: There was a rejoinder affidavit dated July 15, 1960 filed by Radhey Shyam in which reply to Para 10 of the appellants affidavit dated July 6 , 1960 is companytained in Para 8 and it reads as follows Regarding Para 10-2it is false and denied that Chajoo Ram, did number act as Sarpanch till the 7th December, 1957. As a matter of fact he was acting as Sarpanch throughout in violation of the stay order passed against him.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate report dated January 4, 1963 found Chajoo Ram committed irregularities without dishonest motive, no action needed.

anchor.surface_text: According to the report of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate dated January 4, 1963 Chajoo Ram, appellant, was only found lo have companymitted some irregularities in disposing of the cases but without any dishonest motive on his part. In the opinion of the Sub- Divisional Magistrate, numberaction was called for against the appellant.

facts.text: District Magistrate on February 17, 1963 desired further probe; S.D.O. K.P. Mathur endorsed no mala fide intention.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the District Magistrate on February 17, 1963 desired a, further probe into the matter. Shri K. P. Mathur, S.D.O. after going through the records of the Nyaya Panchayat once again endorsed the report of his predecessor observing I also agree with Shri Nageshwar Singh that the allegations had numbermala fide intention, the irregularities that. had been found were due to inexperience or ignorance

facts.text: District Magistrate discharged notice to appellant on May 4, 1964 holding no case of false affidavit made out.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the preliminary enquiry the District Magistrate held that the case of swearing a false affidavit was number made out against the appellant and the numberice issued to him was discharged on May 4, 1964.

facts.text: Sessions Judge upheld District Magistrate order, possibility of conviction remote.

anchor.surface_text: Radhey Shyam took the matter on appeal to the companyrt of the Sessions Judge assailing the order of the District Magistrate dated, May 4, 1964, but without success. That companyrt also came to the companyclusion that the appellant was number shown to have acted as Sarpanch during the period in question.

facts.text: Four receipts nos. 39 to 42 and copy of report by appellant as Sarpanch to Panchayat Raj Officer indicating acting between June 4 and June 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the merits the Division Bench of the High Court observed that the respondent had placed on the record four receipts  number. 39 t0 42  and a companyy of the report supposed to have been submitted by the appellant as Sarpanch to the Panchayat Raj Officer indicating that the appellant had acted as Sarpanch between June 4 and June 6,1957.

facts.text: Appellant explained that Chhotey Lal Sahayak Sarpanch was on leave June 4 to June 11, 1957 and appellant did ministerial work.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants explanation, that Chhotey Lal, Sahayak parpanch was on leave from June, 4 to June 11, 1957 and that the appellant had merely worked for Chhotey Lal in those days, was number accepted for the reason that this explanation was neither included in the affidavit filed by the appellant in reply to the application under s. 476, Cr. P.C.

facts.text: Receipts 59,60 dated June 4, 1957 for 12 ps., 61 dated June 6, 1957, 77 dated June 4, 1957 for 53 ps. summons fee received by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Before us reliance has been placed on four receipts viz. receipt number 59 and 60 dated June 4, 1957 for 12 ps. as price of application form, receipt number 61 dated June 6, 1957 on account of price of application form and receipt number 77 dated June 4, 1957 for 53 ps. on account of summons fee which is said to have been received by the appellant.

facts.text: Report to Panchayat Raj Officer dated June 6, 1957 signed by appellant informing some Panchas had not attended.

anchor.surface_text: The next document on which reliance is placed is a kind of a report to the Panchayat Raj Officer dated June 6, 1957 informing him that some Panchas had number attended since the establishment of the Panchayat.

facts.text: Supreme Court held section 479-A CrPC inapplicable as appellant did not appear as witness, only filed affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the appellant quite clearly did number appear as a witness before the High Court. He undoubtedly filed sworn affidavit but it is number possible to hold that by doing so he companyld be said to have appeared as a witness. Section 479-A, Cr. P. C. is, therefore, inapplicable and it cannot operate as a bar to,, the proceedings under s. 476, Cr P.C.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside order directing complaint, finding no prima facie case of deliberate falsehood.

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are companystrained to allow the appeal and set aside the order directing companyplaint to be filed.

facts.text: Appellant filed affidavit on December 8, 1961 in DM proceedings affirming not acted as Sarpanch for one year.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in those proceedings also the appellant had filed an affidavit on December 8, 1961, affirming that he had number acted as Sarpanch for one year and that Chhotey Lal, Sahayak Sarpanch looked after the work of the, Sarpanch during that period.

facts.text: Radhey Shyam applied under s.476 CrPC in District Magistrate court for appellant's prosecution for false affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: Radhey Shyam, respondent, presented an application tinder s. 476, Cr. P. C. in the companyrt of the District Magistrate also praying for the appellants prosecution- under ss. 193 181 182, I.P.C. for having deliberately filed a false affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution for perjury should be sanctioned by companyrts ,only in those cases where the perjury appears to be deliberate and companyscious and the companyviction is reasonably probable or likely. No doubt giving of false evidence and filing false affidavit is an evil which must be effectively curbed with a strong hand but to start prosecution for perjury too readily and too frequently with,out due care and caution and on inconclusive and doubtful material defeats its very purpose. Prosecution should be ordered when it is companysidered expedient in the interests of justice to punish the delinquent and number merely because there is some inaccuracy in the statement which may be innocent or immaterial. There must be prima facie case of deliberate falsehood on a matter ,of substance and the companyrt should be satisfied that there is reasonable foundation for the charge.

concepts.interpretation: No prima facie deliberate falsehood; material inadequate; long delay; prior findings against prosecution; hence not expedient.

issues.text: The effect of s. 479-A, Cr. P.C. and whether it applies to bar proceedings under s. 476, Cr. P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The first point which was pressed before us relates to the effect of s. 479-A, Cr. P.C. This section was added to the Code of Criminal Procedure by Act 26 of 1955 with the object of eradicating the evils of perjury. It overrides the provisions of ss. 476 to 479.

issues.text: Whether it is expedient in the interests of justice to direct a complaint under s. 476 Cr. P.C. for the appellant's alleged false statement in para 10 of his affidavit dated July 6, 1960 that he had not been acting as Sarpanch till December 7, 1957

anchor.surface_text: Now, the appellant quite clearly did number appear as a witness before the High Court. He undoubtedly filed sworn affidavit but it is number possible to hold that by doing so he companyld be said to have appeared as a witness. Section 479-A, Cr. P. C. is, therefore, inapplicable and it cannot operate as a bar to,, the proceedings under s. 476, Cr P.C. Before dealing with the merits of the case we companysider it proper to refer to the proceedings before the District Magistrate

arguments.claim: Proceedings under s.476 CrPC are barred by s.479A CrPC because the appellant filed a sworn affidavit amounting to appearing as a witness giving false evidence.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal came back to the Division Bench it was urged on behalf of the appellant that in view of the provisions of s. 479-A, Cr. P. C. no prosecution could be taken under s. 476 of the Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ailed before us. The first point which was pressed before us relates to the effect of s. 479-A, Cr. P.C. This section was added to the Code of Crimina

arguments.claim: Person filing affidavit in court cannot be considered to have appeared as witness under s.479A.

anchor.surface_text: This contention was repelled and it was held that a person filing an affidavit in court could not be considered to have appeared as a witness before that court as contemplated by s. 479-A.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; filing sworn affidavit does not mean appearing as witness.

arguments.claim: Prosecution under s.476 requires prima facie deliberate and conscious perjury with reasonable prospect of conviction; expedient only if interests of justice demand, not for innocent inaccuracy.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution for perjury should be sanctioned by courts only in those cases where the perjury appears to be deliberate and conscious and the conviction is reasonably probable or likely. No doubt giving of false evidence and filing false affidavit is an evil which must be effectively curbed with a strong hand but to start prosecution for perjury too readily and too frequently without due care and caution and on inconclusive and doubtful material defeats its very purpose.

arguments.claim: No prima facie case of deliberate falsehood in affidavit para 10; material inadequate; High Court approach mechanical; prior DM and Sessions Judge findings against prosecution; long delay (10+ years).

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are constrained to allow the appeal and set aside the order directing complaint to be filed.

holdings.text: Section 479-A CrPC is inapplicable to bar proceedings under s.476 CrPC because the appellant did not appear as a witness before the High Court; merely filing a sworn affidavit does not constitute appearing as a witness.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the appellant quite clearly did number appear as a witness before the High Court. He undoubtedly filed sworn affidavit but it is number possible to hold that by doing so he companyld be said to have appeared as a witness. Section 479-A, Cr. P. C. is, therefore, inapplicable and it cannot operate as a bar to,, the proceedings under s. 476, Cr P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory textual analysis of s.479A(1): provision applies only to persons 'appearing before it as a witness'; affidavit filing lacks physical/court appearance element.

holdings.text: Courts must sanction perjury prosecutions under s.476 CrPC only where falsehood is deliberate and conscious, conviction reasonably probable or likely, prima facie case exists on substantial matter, and expedient in interests of justice; not for inadvertent or immaterial inaccuracies.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution for perjury should be sanctioned by companyrts ,only in those cases where the perjury appears to be deliberate and companyscious and the companyviction is reasonably probable or likely. No doubt giving of false evidence and filing false affidavit is an evil which must be effectively curbed with a strong hand but to start prosecution for perjury too readily and too frequently with,out due care and caution and on inconclusive and doubtful material defeats its very purpose. Prosecution should be ordered when it is companysidered expedient in the interests of justice to punish the delinquent and number merely because there is some inaccuracy in the statement which may be innocent or immaterial. There must be prima facie case of deliberate falsehood on a matter ,of substance and the companyrt should be satisfied that there is reasonable foundation for the charge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation balancing eradication of perjury evil against preventing frivolous prosecutions through caution on inconclusive material; requires judicial satisfaction of reasonable conviction prospects.

holdings.text: Receipts dated June 4 and 6, 1957 do not establish that appellant acted as Sarpanch; no evidence such functions exclusive to Sarpanch, and Panch could sign receipts while Sahayak Sarpanch on leave.

anchor.surface_text: Before us reliance has been placed on four receipts viz. receipt number 59 and 60 dated June 4, 1957 for 12 ps. as price of application form, receipt number 61 dated June 6, 1957 on account of price of application form and receipt number 77 dated June 4, 1957 for 53 ps. on account of summons fee which is said to have been received by the appellant. On these days, according to the appellant, the Sahayak Sarpanch was on leave. There is numberhing to suggest that this explanation is false and we do number think that on the basis of these three receipts the appellant can be said to have acted as a Sarpanch. It is number shown that this was the function only of the Sarpanch and a Panch companyld in numbercircumstances sign a receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence evaluation: appellant's explanation plausible and uncontradicted; functions not proven exclusive to Sarpanch under Panchayat Raj rules.

holdings.text: Report dated June 6, 1957 to Panchayat Raj Officer does not prove appellant acted or intended to act as Sarpanch; explained as formal document prepared by Secretary with word 'Sarpanch' inserted.

anchor.surface_text: The next document on which reliance is placed is a kind of a report to the Panchayat Raj Officer dated June 6, 1957 informing him that some Panchas had number attended since the establishment of the Panchayat. In this document the appellants signatures and the signatures of the Secretary, B.P. Joshi, both appear below the endorsement forwarding this report to the Panchayat Inspector for information and necessary action. This was explained by the appellant in his affidavit where he stated that the Secretary had inserted the word Sarpanch and on the appellants objection to the use of this word, the Secretary bad replied that this was a formal matter. From this document also we do number think it is possible to hold that the appellant intended to act as Sarpanch on June 6. 1957.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document context and appellant's affidavit explanation accepted as credible; signatures alone insufficient without intent proof.

holdings.text: Not expedient in interests of justice to file complaint under s.476 CrPC for alleged false affidavit; material inadequate, explanation plausible, High Court approach mechanical, prior DM/Sessions findings against prosecution, substantial delay militates against.

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are companystrained to allow the appeal and set aside the order directing companyplaint to be filed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.476 standard to facts: doubtful evidence, consistent explanations/affidavits, weight to concurrent lower findings on same issue, laches (10+ years), mental/financial suffering.

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are constrained to allow the appeal and set aside the order directing companyplaint to be filed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order directing complaint to be filed against appellant for false statement in affidavit set aside; no prosecution directed
